Customer Segmentation Project

Author

Makhdoom Zaheer Ahmed

ğŸ¯ Uncovering Customer Insights with Machine Learning

NoteThe Business Goal

A shopping mall wants to understand its customers better to improve marketing and increase sales. The objective is to identify distinct customer segments based on their demographic information and spending behavior.

This project demonstrates a complete data science workflowâ€”from data cleaning and exploration to machine learning modeling and visualizationâ€”to deliver actionable business insights.

ğŸ“Š The Process at a Glance

The analysis followed a structured, four-step process to ensure robust and reliable results.

  1. Data Exploration & Cleaning: Loaded and inspected the customer data to understand its structure and quality.
  2. Feature Engineering: Selected key features (Annual Income, Spending Score) and scaled them for optimal model performance.
  3. Clustering with K-Means: Applied the K-Means algorithm, using the Elbow Method to determine the ideal number of customer segments.
  4. Visualization & Interpretation: Created a clear visual representation of the clusters and analyzed their characteristics to provide business recommendations.

ğŸ” Key Findings & Actionable Insights

The analysis revealed five distinct customer groups. Understanding these groups allows for highly targeted marketing strategies.

ğŸ’ Target Customers

High Income, High Spending This is the most valuable group. Marketing efforts should focus on retention and loyalty programs.

ğŸ¤” Careful Customers

High Income, Low Spending This group has high potential. They could be targeted with premium offers and personalized recommendations to encourage spending.

âš¡ Careless Customers

Low Income, High Spending While they spend a lot, they are at risk of financial churn. Marketing should focus on value and discounts.

ğŸ§˜ Sensible & Standard Customers

Average/Low Income & Spending These are the largest segments. They respond well to sales, bulk promotions, and budget-friendly options.

The final visualization below clearly shows these five segments, with the red â€˜Xâ€™ marks representing the center of each group.
